awd_titl_txt: Satellite Observations and Modelling of Surface Meltwater Flow and its Impact on Ice Shelves
awd_abstract_narration:
Ice shelves slow the movement of the grounded ice sheets that feed them. This reduces the rate at which ice sheets lose mass to the oceans and contribute to sea-level rise. But ice shelves can be susceptible to collapse, particularly when surface meltwater accumulates in vulnerable areas. Meltwater lakes can create and enlarge fractures within the ice shelves, thereby triggering or hastening ice-shelf collapse. Also, water refreezing within ice shelves warms the ice and could affect the flow of the ice by changing its viscosity, which depends on temperature. The drainage of water across the surface of Antarctica and where it accumulates has received little attention. This drainage was assumed to be insignificant, but recent work shows that meltwater can drain for tens of kilometers across ice-shelf surfaces and access areas that would otherwise not accumulate meltwater. Surface meltwater drainage could play a major role in the future stability of ice sheets. This drainage is the focus of this project. 

The team will develop and test physics-based mathematical models of water flow and ice-shelf flow, closely informed by remote sensing observations, to ask (1) how drainage systems will grow in response to the increased melt rates that are predicted for this century, (2) how this drainage is influenced by ice dynamics and (3) whether enlarged drainage systems could deliver meltwater to areas of ice shelves that are vulnerable to water-driven collapse.  The team hypothesizes that refreezing of meltwater in snow and firn will prove important for hydrology by impacting the permeability of the snow/firn and for ice-shelf dynamics by releasing latent heat within the ice and lowering ice viscosity. The project will examine these issues by (1) conducting a remote sensing survey of the structure and temporal evolution of meltwater systems around Antarctica, (2) developing and analyzing mathematical models of water flow across ice shelves, and (3) examining idealized and realistic models of ice-shelf flow. This project will support a first-time NSF PI, a post-doctoral researcher and a graduate student. An outreach activity will make use of the emerging technology of Augmented Reality to visualize the dynamics of ice sheets in three dimensions to excite the public about glaciology at outreach events around New York City.  This approach will be made publicly available for wider use as Augmented Reality continues to grow in popularity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The flow of the Antarctic Ice Sheet controls how it grows and shrinks and contributes to sea-level change. The floating extensions of the ice sheet, called ice shelves, hold back the flow of the ice sheet. When ice shelves rapidly collapse, the ice sheet flows faster and increases its contribution to sea-level rise. Ice shelves are thought to collapse, in part, because meltwater accumulates on the surface of the ice and flows into and enlarges vertical fractures. Shortly before this project started, we used satellite data to show that water drains long distances across the surface of Antarctica’s ice shelves. This raised the question of how this drainage could affect ice-shelf collapse. This project aimed to start answering this question.

 

The main outcomes of the project are related to 1) the professional development of the project team, 2) our understanding of drainage systems, 3) our understanding of why drainage is important, which related to the fact that water can cause fracturing in some places more easily than it can in others, and 4) the public’s knowledge of glaciology and the small, but growing field of Antarctic surface hydrology.

 

Professional development: The project supported an early-career professor (the PI), three post-doctoral researchers, and a graduate student. All five gained valuable broad experience and domain-specific knowledge from their involvement in the project. Two of the postdocs have gone on to academic positions at Stanford and the European Space Agency (the other is still at Columbia). The graduate student is working for the Georgia state government as a hydrology modeler. This is key way in which this project had broader impact.

 

Understanding of drainage systems: We presented one of the most detailed looks at an ice-shelf drainage system. This was based on satellite observations and showed that the size that drainage system grows to varies year to year, and this is controlled not just by how much melting there is (i.e., the weather), but on how large the drainage system grew to the previous year. This has interesting implications for how quickly drainage systems will grow in the future. This is one of the intellectual merits of this project.

 

Understanding of why drainage is important: We showed that the vulnerability of ice shelves to fracturing caused by meltwater varies significantly in space; around 60% of ice shelves by area are vulnerable to this kind of fracturing, with the vulnerable areas generally lying nearest the ocean. This shows how important drainage systems are because they tend to move water from areas upstream, where melting happens, towards these more vulnerable areas downstream. The implication is that if drainage systems grow in the future, they will deliver water to the most vulnerable areas and potentially cause ice shelves to fracture and even collapse. This is another of the intellectual merits of this project.

 

Public understanding of Antarctic surface hydrology: Through engagement with the public in many venues, including our research institution’s annual open house that attracts thousands of visitors, the project team have increased public understanding of glaciology and our sub-field specifically. These engagements included practical demonstrations of glaciological processes, public lectures, and school visits. This is another way in which this project had broader impact.
